author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Hello, I am an automated registration bot. I help manage the registration process by checking your registration against a set of [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). If all these guidelines are met, this pull request will be merged automatically, completing your registration. It is **strongly recommended** to follow the guidelines, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

## 1. New package registration

Please make sure that you have read the [package naming guidelines](https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1).

## 2. [AutoMerge Guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/) are all met! âœ…

Your new package registration met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

## 3. To pause or stop registration

If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. 

_Tip: You can edit blocking comments to add `[noblock]` in order to unblock auto-merging._

<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

Hi, congrats on the new package!
As a maintainer of the [JuliaGraphs](https://juliagraphs.org/) organization, I would like to suggest a more specific name like `DirectedAcyclicGraphComputing`. Otherwise users may mistake your library for a generic graph algorithms package.
As a side note, are you aware of [Dagger.jl](https://github.com/JuliaParallel/Dagger.jl)? Ping @jpsamaroo

Hey, thanks.
I can see that the name may be confusing... I dislike the suggestion though, because it seems harder to remember, and it being a directed acyclic graph isn't really the core of the things the package provides. Maybe I can come up with a better idea still.

> As a side note, are you aware of [Dagger.jl](https://github.com/JuliaParallel/Dagger.jl)?

I'm aware of the package, yes, but I decided to use my own implementation of a graph to have very specific control of the metadata I can store in it. I'm aware that my graph representation is not the prettiest or fastest at the moment, but I have some plans to improve this. It has worked well enough until now though.

You are right that Dagger.jl provides a similar functionality, but the focus of this package is much more to create very large graphs of very small and repeating computations, and optimizing this graph before actually executing it. 

I'm working on a directly implemented test model that I could also put in a manual, but for now you can see https://github.com/GraphComputing-jl/QEDFeynman.jl for an example (I don't plan to release that specific package, but a similar and improved one relying on this).

Longer names are never a bad thing in the Julia package ecosystem, people can always do
```julia
import LongPackageNameICanNeverRemember as LPNICNR
```

I'm generally in agreement with @gdalle , and would recommend a name that doesn't make it sound as if your package satisfies all graph computational use cases. Maybe FastDAGs.jl, ComputableDAGs.jl, etc.
I think I like ComputableDAGs, I will think about/start renaming tomorrow. Thanks for the suggestions!

The new PR after renaming is here: https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/114592
This PR can therefore be closed

body:
